title: What Is a Negative Exposure Assessment (NEA)?
summary: Learn what a Negative Exposure Assessment is, when it’s required, and how it protects workers and contractors under OSHA regulations.

sections.heading: What Is a Negative Exposure Assessment (NEA)?
body: A Negative Exposure Assessment (NEA) is a documented determination that employee exposures to a hazardous substance are below the OSHA Permissible Exposure Limit (PEL) under specific work conditions.
NEAs are commonly used in asbestos, lead, silica, and other industrial hygiene programs to demonstrate that controls are effective and that certain regulatory requirements may be reduced.

sections.heading: Why NEAs Matter
body: An NEA helps employers demonstrate compliance with OSHA standards, support safe work practices, and provide defensible documentation during inspections.
Under OSHA 29 CFR 1926.1101, employers may use an NEA to show asbestos exposures are below the PEL when proper controls are in place.

sections.heading: When Is an NEA Required?
body: You may need an NEA when performing asbestos abatement, conducting lead paint removal, cutting silica-containing materials, introducing new processes, or responding to worker exposure concerns.
If work conditions change, the NEA must be reevaluated to ensure exposures remain below regulatory limits.

sections.heading: What an NEA Includes
body: A complete NEA documents project and site information, descriptions of operations, engineering controls, air monitoring methods, sampling results, TWA calculations, and a final determination.
This documentation supports compliance and provides a defensible record of exposure evaluation.

sections.heading: Common Misconceptions
body: An NEA does not eliminate safety requirements. Controls must remain in place, work practices must remain consistent, and reassessment is required if conditions change.
The NEA is valid only under the conditions observed during monitoring.

sections.heading: How AbateIQ Simplifies NEAs
body: AbateIQ helps environmental professionals link air monitoring results directly to NEAs, auto-calculate TWAs, generate client-ready reports, and maintain defensible audit trails.
By centralizing data and workflows, AbateIQ reduces administrative burden while improving compliance confidence.

sections.heading: Final Thoughts
body: A Negative Exposure Assessment is more than paperwork — it’s a critical tool for protecting workers, ensuring compliance, and demonstrating professional due diligence.
If your team performs hazardous material work, a clear and defensible NEA process is essential.

faqs.question: Does an NEA eliminate the need for PPE?
faqs.answer: No. PPE requirements depend on regulations and site conditions. An NEA may support adjustments but does not automatically remove PPE requirements.

faqs.question: How long is an NEA valid?
faqs.answer: An NEA remains valid only while work conditions, materials, and controls remain unchanged. Any changes require reevaluation.
